title.value: Optimal control of network-coupled subsystems: Spectral decomposition and low-dimensional solutions
title.justification: The title is provided directly at the beginning of the paper, identifying the main focus and methodology used in the research: optimal control and spectral decomposition.
title.quote: Optimal control of network-coupled subsystems: Spectral decomposition and low-dimensional solutions

extractions.description: This paper investigates the optimal control of network-coupled subsystems through spectral decomposition techniques, enabling scalable control solutions for large-scale systems by leveraging the properties of graph theory. It focuses on decomposing systems based on the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of coupling matrices, reducing the complexity of control problems significantly.

type.justification: The paper presents a theoretical investigation into control systems using spectral decomposition, as indicated by its focus on theoretical aspects such as eigenvalues, eigenvectors, and Riccati equations without empirical experimentation.
type.quote: A key feature which distinguishes our approach from these previous work is that our approach is applicable to models where the coupling between agents are not homogeneous and that we establish optimal solutions rather than an approximate solution.

name.justification: The paper is centered on control theory, specifically focusing on optimal control methods for systems connected via network structures, a common subject within control theory.
name.quote: In this paper, we investigate optimal control of network-coupled subsystems where the dynamics and the cost couplings depend on an underlying undirected weighted graph.

name.justification: Graph theory is a sub-field discussed due to the use of graphs to represent and analyze the connections and relationships among the subsystems.
name.quote: We use the spectral decomposition of the graph coupling matrix to decompose the overall system into (L + 1) systems with decoupled dynamics and cost.

name.justification: The paper considers multiple subsystems connected over a network, suggesting an influence from systems theory regarding how these subsystems interact.
name.quote: Consider a network consisting of n nodes connected over an undirected weighted graph G(N , E, W), where N ={1, . . . , n} is the set of nodes.
